metadata.title: One Dimensional Silver-based Nanomaterials: Preparations and Electrochemical Applications

sections.text:
© 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.small-journal.com (1 of 18) 1701091
Silver-based Nanomaterials
One Dimensional Silver-based Nanomaterials: Preparations and Electrochemical Applications Qunxing Zhao, Mingming Zhao, Jiaqing Qiu, Wen-Yong Lai,* Huan Pang,* and Wei Huang*
One dimensional (1D) silver-based nanomaterials have a great potential in various fields because of their high specific surface area, high electric conductivity, optoelectronic properties, mechanical flexibility and high electro-catalytic efficiency. In this Review, the preparations of 1D silver-based nanomaterials is classified by structure composed of simple silver nanowires/rods/belts/tubes, core-shells, and hybrids. The latest applications based on 1D silver nanomaterials and their composite materials are summarized systematically including electrochemical capacitors, lithium-ion/lithium-oxygen batteries, electrochemical sensors and electrochemical catalysis. The preparation process, tailored material properties and electrochemical applications are discussed.
1. Introduction ..............................................2
2. Preparations ..............................................2
3. Electrochemical Applications .....................8
4. Conclusions and Outlook .........................15

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Due to the fossil energy depletion and global warming, it is crucial to meet the needs of sustainable energy production, storage, and consumption.[1–3] To cope with this issue, energy conversion and storage devices have drawn great attention in the past decades.[4–11] Newly developed electrochemical devices such as rechargeable batteries, supercapacitors, electrochemical sensors and catalysis have become prospective candidates owing to their high feasibility, environmentally friendliness, and sustainability.[12–23]
The design and creation of new materials and substances that are chemically modified from the molecular and atomic level to nanoscale sizes would offer significantly enhanced functions for electrochemical applications. Nanomaterials are being explored for their attractive chemical and physical properties for electrochemical applications. The characteristics of small particle size and high specific surface area make it promising for 1D nanomaterials to be applied in electrochemical devices.[24–29] Large specific surface area and numerous exposed surface atoms caused by the 1D nanostructure lead to large contact areas for active sites and electrolytes, which would significantly improve the reaction activity of inorganic lattices in the process of electrochemical reactions.[30–35] Moreover, 1D nanomaterials are capable of being assembled into thin films with two dimensional hybrid networks via a layer by layer method, showing the promise of being integrated into flexible in-plane electrochemical devices.[36–45] The high-performance electrochemical devices need high conductive current collectors and active materials. 1D silver-based materials can be easily synthesized at low cost, exhibiting a great potential to be used in electrochemical devices due to their high electric conductivity and catalytic performance. Electrical conductivity and thermal conductivity of silver are 6.301 × 107 S m−1 and 429 W m−1 K−1), respectively, which are the highest in all metals. Compositing silver into active materials with various morphologies can dramatically enhance the electrical and thermal properties.[46–48] As a potential substitute for the Pt catalyst, silver also has been more in-depth researched for electrocatalysis in comparison with other catalysts because of its lower cost, more abundance and higher oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) activity. Among Ag-based nanomaterials, silver nanowires (Ag NWs) have attained great attention due to their thin diameter and high aspect ratio, making it efficient to contact with electrolyte and prompting fast electron transfer in the process of electrochemical reactions. Besides, they also exhibit excellent light transmission and flexible bending resistance due to the nanometer size effect. The percolation pathways are easily formed with a very low loading of Ag NWs in comparison with that of silver particles as fillers. Accordingly, the properties and electrochemical applications of Ag NWs have been largely investigated.
Recent progress has demonstrated that 1D silver-based nanomaterials could be applied to high-performance electrochemical energy storage and conversion devices. This article reviews the advancements and trends in 1D Ag NWs, silver nanorods, silver nanobelts and silver-based nanomaterials such as alloys, silver/carbon (silver/non-metal/carbon),
silver/metal, silver/metal oxides, silver/layered double hydroxides (LDHs), silver/Prussian blue nanocubes (PBNCs), silver/polymer for supercapacitors, Li-ion batteries, electrochemical sensors and catalysis. The representative structures of 1D silver nanomaterials (Ag NWs, silver nanorods, silver nanobelts) are shown in Figure 1.[61–63] As the structure is very important for electrochemical performance, we will first focus on synthesis and properties of 1D silver-based nanomaterials with various structures followed by electrochemical applications. The relationships between the material structures and electrochemical performance as well as the related mechanisms are discussed. This paper ends with conclusions and prospects of silver-based nanomaterials in future development of electrochemical energy storage devices and conversion systems.

sections.heading: 2.1. Simple Nanowires/Rods/Belts/Tubes
sections.text:
A large number of methods have been studied to prepare 1D silver nanostructures.[49–66] For example, various synthetic strategies applied to Ag NWs have flourished in the past few decades, such as solvothermal method,[52,53] polyol process,[54,55] photo-reduction technique, electro-deposition process,[56] ultraviolet irradiation,[57] porous material template method,[58] DNA template method[59] and wet chemical method.[60] In this part, we will briefly introduce two synthesis methods: seed-mediated growth, polyol reduction. Seed-mediated growth is a common method to synthesize Ag NWs. With the help of capping molecules, it can be intensively integrated to the sides of Ag NWs to prevent them from aggregation and accelerate anisotropic growth. It always needs good conditions to separate the sequential nucleation
small 2017, 1701091
www.advancedsciencenews.com
(3 of 18) 1701091© 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.small-journal.com
from growth steps to create the antisymmetric geometry in Ag NWs during their growth. The nuclei formed at the nucleation process exhibited a specific crystalline structure, which can initially enlarge the anisotropic pattern of nuclei in the growth process. The bonding strength is different between the sides and ends of Ag NWs as the capping molecules provide an additional driving force for the anisotropic growth. Better separation of the two steps leads to high yield, quality of Ag NWs. As the capping agents, surfactant molecules such as sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS), tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB), dodecyl benzene sulfonic acid sodium (DBS) are usually used to synthesize Ag NWs.[61]
1D silver nanomaterials were also synthesized via a polyol reduction strategy, and this method was widely studied. Silver precursors were slowly introduced to reaction systems by using syringe pumps. With the help of polymeric surfactants like polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP) which was developed by Sun and Xia,[54,55] silver precursors were reduced by polyol, representing one of the most successful ways to synthesize high quality and yield Ag NWs. Taking Cheng’s work for example, the length of the Ag NWs could reach up to 80 µm with a diameter of ≈50 nm, indicating a high aspect ratio of 1600. The silver nitrate was added within 9–12 min. After being completely added, the reaction solution turned into a grey liquid in 15–20 min, proving that the silver ions have been translated into silver nanoparticles (Ag NPs). After about 25 min, the short silver nanorods were formed. Long Ag NWs were formed after about 40 min. After about 50 min, almost all the Ag NPs have grown into the long Ag NWs.[49]
1D silver alloys have been synthesized by various methods.[69–71] Yang et al. reported the synthesis of goldsilver nanotubes (Au-AgNTs) through a PVP-mediated polyol way adopting a replacement reaction with Ag NWs.[69] The Ag NWs were synthesized by a polyol method and then added into PVP/NaCl aqueous solution under magnetic stirring. Subsequently, HAuCl4 solution was injected into the dispersion. After two hours, Au-AgNTs were obtained. Hong et al. developed a simple hydrothermal method to synthesize PdAgTe nanowires (NWs). Te NWs were employed as sacrificial templates. The high-quality PdAgTe NWs were obtained by a partial galvanic replacement reaction between the Te NWs and corresponding noble metal salts in aqueous solution. Compositions of the alloy NWs were able to be changed by changing the concentration of precursors.[70]

sections.heading: 2.2. 1D Core-Shell Nanostructure
sections.text:
1D core-shell structure has high conductivity and low carrier transfer rate for electrochemical reactions. This nanostructure can obviously reduce resistance derived from electrolytical diffusion in the process of rapid charge/discharge reactions. Many synthetic methods have been employed to use 1D nanomaterials as the backbone to support materials to form the core-shell architecture.[67,68] Through seed mediated growth way, bimetallic NWs (Ag@Cu NWs) can be synthesized on the surface of modified electrodes. Ag seeds (Agseeds) were generated on a glassy carbon (GC) electrode and mediate the growth of Cu. CTAB acted as a soft

template followed by stabilizing agent in controlling the size of NWs, as shown in Figure 2a.[68]
Moon et al. developed a direct electropolymerization of conducting polymer method on a metal NW network by introducing an ultrathin gold layer sheath on Ag NWs to achieve an Ag/Au/conducting polymer core-shell NW, the fabrication step is described in Figure 2b. The electrochemical stability of Ag NWs is significantly enhanced after covering its whole surface with a gold layer of 3–5 nm through galvanic replacement-free deposition, while maintaining the electrical conductivity and optical transmittance of its percolation network.[73] Yuksel et al. synthesized a novel material composed of molybdenum (IV) oxide (MoO2) shell on Ag NW core in the network form. Ag NWs were simply spray coated onto glass substrates to form conductive networks

and conformal MoO2 layer was electrodeposited onto the Ag NW network to create binder-free coaxial supercapacitor electrodes.[72]
Hydrothermal method has also been employed to synthesize 1D silver-based core-shell nanomaterials. The first step of the experiment is to form amorphous metal salts on the Ag NWs. The nascent precursor attaches to the Ag NWs and functions as sites of the nucleation. Then, nucleation and growth can occur via an aggregation-based mechanism forming crystals with hierarchical architectures; hierarchical NiAl LDH nanosheets are growing uniformly on the Ag NWs. By this method, Wu et al. prepared core-shell Ag NW@ hierarchical NiAl LDH. The formation process is shown in Figure 2c.[74]

sections.heading: 2.3. Hybrid Nanostructure
sections.text:
Spin coating technique has been widely used to synthesize hybrid nanostructures. Employing this technique, Yu et al. synthesized a Ag/poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene)-poly(4styrenesulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS)/MnO2 layer by layer structure. Electrons can be easily transported through the Ag NWs network to PEDOT:PSS-nanopillars and MnO2 layers. Figure 3a showed the fabrication steps for Ag/ PEDOT:PSS/ MnO2. A thin PEDOT:PSS nanolayer was spincoated onto
a silicon nanohole mold. Then Ag NWs solution was spincoated onto the prepared PEDOT:PSS layer. To remove previous two layers, polyacrylonitrile (PAN) as an additional layer was spincoated onto above layers, functioning as an adhesive layer in order to peel off the underlying layers in the mold. After coating the thin MnO2 layer onto the PEDOT:PSS-layer through an electro-deposition process, the hybrid nanostructure was obtained.[75] Shen et al. firstly developed a high-efficiency strategy to fabricate flexible electrochromic supercapacitor electrodes, as shown in Figure 3b. First, one-layer PDMS elastomer was spin-coated onto polyethylene terephthalate (PET). Subsequently, Ag NWs ethanol solution was dissolved in deionized water, then vacuum filtered on a filter membrane. Since filtration, the Ag NWs film was readily transferred from a filter membrane to a pre-cured flexible substrate through uniform pressure to receive an anticipated flexible transparent conducting (FTC) substrate. In the end, the uniform WO3 film (a thickness of ∼600 nm) was directly deposited onto the FTC substrate via a simple thermal evaporation method.[76] Wu et al. successfully fabricated an amperometric cholesterol biosensor where zinc oxide nanocrystals were spin-coated on a Ag NWs-graphene oxide (GO) modified electrode as shown in Figure 3c.[77]
As a dynamic flow-driven assembly process, vacuumfiltration method possesses several unique advantages, such as easy processing, low cost, film homogeneity, easy

www.advancedsciencenews.com

thickness control and high yield. Via a simple vacuum filtration method, Liu et al. prepared GO/MnO2/Ag NW (GMA) ternary hybrids as shown in Figure 4a. After filtration, the cellulose acetate membrane is intimately and uniformly covered by GMA ternary hybrid as shown in Figure 4b. Subsequently, the as-prepared GMA ternary hybrid film could act as active materials for fabricating MSCs as shown in Figure 4c. In brief, the GMA ternary hybrids film on a cellulose acetate membrane was transferred onto an alumina substrate. A designed configuration Gold pattern was thermally evaporated to the GMA ternary hybrids film via a homemade interdigital finger mask. Afterward, the Au layer acts as a protection layer to corrode the exposed GO by O2 plasma, and then residual Ag NWs and MnO2 could be removed by

HCl aqueous solution. In the end, a thermal reduction was carried out through annealing the device at 300 °C for 2 h under Ar atmosphere.[78] Tang et al. fabricated the integrated Si/Ag NWs/reduced graphene oxide (rGO) composite film via introducing binary conductive networks between Ag NWs and rGO into the Si active materials by a simple vacuumfiltration method. The active Si NPs can be homogeneously encapsulated through binary conductive network with Ag NWs-rGO where Ag NWs have been interwoven with the rGO sheet. The synthesis process is described in Figure 4d.[79]
Wang et al. have reported synthesis of biomimetic Ag NWs templated by peptide nanofibers (PNFs) (PNF-AgNW) and the subsequent electrostatic assembly of the synthesized PNF-AgNW onto graphene nanosheets (GNs) to fabricate GN-PNF-AgNW nanohybrids. Figure 5 shows a schematic representation for the synthesis of GN-PNF-AgNW nanohybrids by electrostatic assembling PNF-AgNW nano hybrids onto polymer-modified GNs. First, GO nanosheets were chemically reduced into GNs by glucose, and the ζ potential of the obtained GNs was −26.05 mV. Second, the synthesized GNs were modified with a positive-charged polymer, poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride) (PDDA), to obtain PDDA-GNs with a ζ potential (+35.87 mV). Third, PNFs were fabricated via the controllable self-assembly method of specifically designing peptide molecules; the synthesized artificial PNFs generated PNF-AgNW nanohybrids (ζ potential of −16.39 mV). Finally, the PNF-AgNW nanohybrids were self-assembled onto the surface of GNs by electrostatic interaction due to the big gap between ζ potential of PNF-AgNW nanohybrids and PDDA-GNs (−16.39 vs +35.87 mV).[80]
small 2017, 1701091
www.advancedsciencenews.com
(7 of 18) 1701091© 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.small-journal.com
Zhi et al. fabricated novel Ag NWs/3D-graphene (GF) foam/ordered mesoporous carbon (OMC) (Ag-GF-OMC) as electrodes (Figure 6a). The 3D GF with a weight density of 0.70–0.75 mg cm−1 was obtained by depositing it on Ni foam with the help of chemical vapor at atmospheric pressure for 10 min, followed by removing the Ni foam. The OMC film was coated on the surface of 3D GF through a self-assembly (EISA) process. Afterward, the 3D GF was immersed into ethanol solution with F127 as a template and resol as a carbon precursor. The precursor solution was uniformly adsorbed on the surface of GF networks. The GF-OMC was prepared after a carbonization process at 350 °C under Ar atmosphere. Finally, Ag NWs were coated on the surface of carbon networks.[81] Xu et al. reported a 3D biosensing film consisting of PBNCs and a Ag NW network (Figure 6b). The electrode surface was successfully decorated with the Ag NW network through a self-assembled monolayers (SAMs) process, while PBNCs are in situ preparation on the Ag NW network by an aerosol deposition approach; glucose oxidase (GOx) was immobilized onto the surface of the PBNCs/Ag NWs film by a glutaraldehyde cross-linking method.[82] Patil et al. reported the synthesis of silver-poly(3,4-ethylenedioxy thiophene):poly(styrene sulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS)/polyaniline (PANI) (Ag-PEDOT:PSS/PANI) by dip-coating and

then potentiodynamic electrodeposition (Figure 6c). The PEDOT:PSS matrix was decorated with Ag NWs and Ag NPs to promote its conductivity. Moreover, it could be used as a current collector for further coating of PANI.[83]

sections.heading: 3.1. Electrochemical Capacitors
sections.text:
Nanomaterials with modified design or structure would extremely promote charge storage and reduce internal resistance. Compared with indium tin oxide thin films (ITO), Ag NW network exhibited a comparable transparency and sheet resistance. The Ag NW network acting as transparent conducting materials started in diverse devices, like transparent film heaters,[84] stretchable devices,[85] polymeric light emitting diodes[86] and organic solar cells.[87] The Ag NW network also has potential for supercapacitor due to its high conductivity, mechanical stability (long lifetime) and large surface area (leading to a high power density).[86] Ag NWs in the form of network typically produce a greater current for practical storage device applications. Due to the high aspect ratio of NWs, low sheet resistance is easily obtained with low-
density NWs. Hence, Ag NWs were applied in supercapacitor devices as good as ITO and PEDOT:PSS. Ag NWs also can considerably enhance the mechanical flexibility of the electrode due to its network structure. In this part, we will focus on the 1D silver-based nanomaterials with two structures of core-shell and hybrid for supercapacitors.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. 1D Core-Shell Nanostructure
sections.text:
As for high efficient supercapacitor devices, it is vital to integrate active materials with current collectors. 1D core-shell nanostructures can solve this issue and avoid waste of additional conducting materials. 1D core-shell nanomaterials have been utilized for designing flexible supercapacitors, where NWs were employed as the core.[88–92] Among the core materials, Ag NWs are suitable due to their high conductivity and mechanical flexibility.
Lately, much effort has been made to fabricate transparent, flexible, and stretchable (TFS) supercapacitors. To improve mechanical flexibility, most of the TFS supercapacitors employed nanomaterials such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs), graphene and metal NWs. Most recently, researches have focused not only on the flexibility and stretchability of devices, but also improving their specific capacitances by
small 2017, 1701091
www.advancedsciencenews.com
(9 of 18) 1701091© 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.small-journal.com
fabricating interconnected nano-cup structures or changing surface properties (using redox-active materials). Moon et al. demonstrated a highly transparent and stretchable supercapacitor by adopting Ag/Au/polypyrrole core-shell NW networks as electrodes. The Ag/Au/polypyrrole coreshell NW network exhibited superior mechanical stability under various times mechanical bending (Figure 7b,c,f,g) and stretching (Figure 7j,k). The relative resistance showed almost no changes between 0.99–1.01 in both cases (red lines for Ag/Au/PPy NW and blue line for Ag/Au NW), as shown in Figure 7b. This result indicated that the PPy did not cause any negative effect on the tight junction between NWs. Figure 7c shows the Cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves under different bending conditions ranging from 6 to 30 mm of bending radius. The supercapacitor did not lose any performance. Moreover, the supercapacitor was subjected to cyclic bending (see insets in Figure 7f) and capacitances were measured after each 50 bending cycles. It can retain 93% of the initial capacitance for 1000 bending cycles. To demonstrate the supercapacitor can be applied for wearable devices as power source, the above three supercapacitors were connected in series as shown in Figure 7g. The connected supercapacitors can light a LED after 10 seconds of charging. To demonstrate its stretchable performance, Ag/Au/PPy core-shell NW mesh was fabricated on a stretchable polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) substrate. Figure 7j showed the electrical resistance change of an Au/Ag/PPy core-shell NW network mesh film. For the first cycle, the relative resistance (R/R0) increased up to 8 at 30% strain, and it recovered to 2 after being released from the stretched state. As the strain cycle number increased to 100, the relative resistance decreased and eventually reached steady values, which were ∼3 and 1 for 30% and 0% strain conditions respectively. The fabricated supercapacitor showed high electrical stability under stretching due to the well maintained structure of NW network. Lastly, CV was conducted to verify the stability of the supercapacitor against tensile strain up to 50%, as shown in insets of Figure 7k. The CV curves were almost unchanged as the supercapacitor was stretched from 10 to 50% strain. This result demonstrated that the Ag/Au/PPy core-shell NW mesh structure could be used for stretchable energy devices. In addition, the supercapacitors showed a high optical transmittance together with a fivefold enhanced areal capacitance compared to the pristine Ag/Au core-shell NW mesh-based supercapacitors.[73] Metal oxides and metal hydroxides also have been employed in core-shell NW based supercapacitors. For example, Yuksel et al. synthesized a coaxial composite (core: Ag NWs, shell: MoO2) to fabricate supercapacitor electrodes.

www.advancedsciencenews.com
1701091 (10 of 18) www.small-journal.com © 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
reviews
Because of the pseudocapacitive MoO2 and high conductive Ag NWs, the supercapacitor delivered a high capacitance of 500.7 F g−1 at a current density of 0.25 A g−1 in 1.0 M LiClO4. The electrode also showed an outstanding capacity retention even after 5000 cycles.[72] They also presented another coaxial architecture composed of Ag NW core and nickel hydroxide (Ni(OH)2) shell as electrode materials for supercapacitors. Synergy of highly conductive Ag NWs and high capacitive Ni(OH)2 facilitates ion and electron transport, enhances electrochemical properties and results in a high specific capacitance (1165.2 F g−1) at 3 A g−1. After 3000 cycles, the electrode showed 93% capacity retention.[99] LDHs are eminent pseudocapacitance materials on account of their intriguing features, including versatility in the matrix composition, high redoxactivity, low cost, and environmental benignity.[93] However, satisfactory capacitance performance was rarely achieved because of their poor electrical conductivity and aggregation of active species. To exploit the potential of
small 2017, 1701091
www.advancedsciencenews.com
LDHs-based materials for pseudocapacitors, one promising method is to form nanocomposite by utilizing a substrate to support LDHs.[94–98] For example, Wu et al. synthesized 1D core-shell Ag NW@NiAl LDH as electrode materials for supercapacitors. The NiAl LDH nanosheets grafted vertically on Ag NWs.[74] The 1D core-shell architecture can support efficient contact between the active material and electrolyte, facilitate the transport of ions and electrons and buffer volume change, resulting in a high specific capacitance, fast oxidation-reduction reaction kinetics and good cycle stability.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Hybrid Nanostructure
sections.text:
1D Ag based hybrids also have been used for the fabrication of high-performance supercapacitors. OMC is a kind of promising electrode materials for electric double layer capacitors (EDLC) because of its low cost, high specific surface area, and easily accessed ordered pore channels. However, the pristine OMC electrode suffers from poor electrical conductivity and mechanical flexibility. For further improving its performance, OMC was coated on the surface of 3D graphene foam, which acted as a flexible charge collector.[126] Upon decoration with Ag NWs, Ag-GF-OMC showed an excellent electrical conductivity and mechanical flexibility. Using the Ag-GF-OMC as electrodes, a flexible binder-free supercapacitor was designed (Figure 7a). The supercapacitor under different states (flat, bending) were shown in Figure 7d,e. This work provided a novel way to improve the performances of OMC based supercapacitors.[81] Another kind of flexible supercapacitors based on Ag NWs was fabricated by sandwiching a porous separator (pre-dipped into Na2SO4 aqueous electrolyte) between two Ag-NW/PEDOT:PSS-NP/MnO2 electrodes (Figure 7l). The CV curves did not change significantly at various bend angles (Figure 7m). They also carried out a bend test by bending the supercapacitor for different bend times (0 to 180 angle for 0–100 times) (Figure 7n). Approximately 98% capacitance retained after bending for 100 times at 180o, proving the excellent mechanical stability of the device. Figure 7h showed the Ragone plots of devices both in this work and recent reports for comparison. The
device in this work exhibited a relative high power density and energy density. The assembled two supercapacitors in series can power a light-emitting diode (LED) for 20 min after charging at 1 mA for 30 s (Figure 7i).[75]
Microsupercapacitors (MSCs) are a kind of important energy storage devices. There remains a challenge to improve performances of the MSCs within limited surface area. To solve this issue, Liu et al. fabricated rGO/MnO2/ Ag NWs (RGMA) hybrid films. The Ag NWs act as a conducting bridge between needle-like MnO2 and graphene sheets to improve the electrical conductivity and mechanical flexibility of the film. The “spacer” can prevent the graphene nanosheets from aggregating. The as-prepared RGMA hybrid film was then directly used as electrodes for RGMA-MSCs, exhibiting superior electrochemical performances such as high rate capability (50000 mV s−1), fast frequency response (τ0 = 0.14 ms), and high cycle stability (90.3% of capacitance retention after 6000 cycles).[78]
We compared the electrochemical capacitor performance of previously reported 1D Ag-based nanomaterials, as summarized in Table 1.

sections.heading: 3.2. Lithium–Ion/Lithium–Oxygen batteries
sections.text:
There are continuous efforts in the pursuit of high-performance lithium ion batteries (high energy/power density) to meet the increasing demand of modern electronics and transportation.[100,101] In parallel with the research of advanced cathode materials, stable high capacity anode is another research focus for LIBs.
Among the anode materials for LIBs, Si is promising due to natural abundance, low cost as well as high theoretical capacity (4200 mAh g−1 at room temperature, corresponding to the Li22Si5 alloy). However, Si suffers from two important issues such as low electrical conductivity (1.56 × 10−3 S m−1), large volume change (>300%). For the first issue, which results in low reaction kinetics, low rate capability and poor utilization of active materials. The second issue is pulverization and deterioration of active materials during cycling, which results in poor cycling stability. Designing conductive
www.advancedsciencenews.com
1701091 (12 of 18) www.small-journal.com © 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
reviews nanocomposites is very important for constructing high-performance Si-based anodes. A homogeneous conductive network of rGO/Ag can enhance mechanical stability of Si-based composite electrodes. In the case of Si/rGO/Ag composite electrodes, cycling performance was determined at 50 mA g−1 (voltage range: 0.01 V to 1.5 V), as shown in Figure 8a. The irreversible capacity was ascribed to its SEI layer as well as utilization of graphene. The first Coulombic efficiency of the Si/rGO/Ag film electrode was about 63%. After 50 cycles, its specific capacity reached 1269 mAh g−1. The electrochemical performances were compared with Si/rGO electrodes under the same condition as shown in Figure 8b. The Si/rGO/Ag film electrode exhibited a much higher reversible capacity than the Si/rGO electrode. The reversible capacities of Si/ rGO/Ag film electrodes at the current density of 200, 500, 1000 mA g−1 were 1190, 780, 587 mAh g−1, respectively. After 80 cycles, the capacity of the Si/rGO/Ag film electrode was 816 mAh g−1 (current density: 200 mA g−1) (Figure 8c). Nyquist plots of the Si/rGO electrode and Si/rGO/Ag film electrode were measured. Apparently, the diameter of the Si/
small 2017, 1701091
www.advancedsciencenews.com
(13 of 18) 1701091© 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.small-journal.comsmall 2017, 1701091
www.advancedsciencenews.com
rGO electrode was much larger than that of the Si/rGO/Ag composite film electrode as a result of the higher electrical conductivity and lower electron-transfer resistance for Si/ rGO/Ag film electrode. The rGO/Ag network can preserve high electronic conductivity and good pervasion of Li+ and accordingly reduce the internal resistance. This can be attributed to the reduction of the volume change in the process of metal anode in the loop after other metal elements were added in the active metal.[79]
Newly, silver has also been studied as cathode electrocatalysts to promote hydrogen or oxygen peroxide reduction.[102,103] In ORR, there exists an efficient four-electron reduction for silver.[100] From the previous ORR research by employing Ag catalysts, nano-sized Ag has a higher catalytic activity than the bulk Ag.[103] However, previous studies mainly focused on Ag NPs. The electrocatalytic activity research about 1D metal nanomaterials is still scarce. Kwak et al. adopted Ag NWs as catalytic cathode materials for Li-O2 batteries. The high aspect ratio of Ag NWs promoted the formation of corn-shaped layer structure. The poor crystalline lithium peroxide (Li2O2) NPs were formed by oxygen reduction in a poly ether based electrolyte solution (Figure 8d). The 1D structure of NWs can provide facile electron supply and a large contact area for the efficient ORR. Upon oxygen evolution, Li2O2 with novel structure and the Ag NWs with high catalytic activity promoted Li2O2 decomposition at a low potential (less than 3.4 V), which avoids oxidation of electrodes and decomposition of solution species in the anodic reaction, leading to high-efficient Li-O2 batteries.[104]

sections.heading: 3.3.1. Simple NWs
sections.text: Chemically modified electrodes based on metallic NWs have been employed for improving the electrochemical sensor performance.[105–111] The NWs on the electrode introduced a roughened, high conductivity and high-surface area surface, which can highly improve the catalytic activity of the electrode.[112–118] Ag NWs modified electrodes exhibited excellent performance such as high Faradaic current density, fast electron transfer rate, high signal-to-noise ratio, low detection limit and high sensitivity. The excellent performance originated from various advantages of the electrode: facile pathways to transfer electrons and efficient surface exposure at the interface of electrode-electrolyte, all of which were especially important for electrochemical sensors. As an enzyme-free sensor, the Ag NWs/Pt electrode had wide linear range to H2O2 (0.5 µM–30 mM), high sensitivity (9.45 µA mM−1), low detection limit of 0.2 µM (S/N = 3) and fast response time (within 5 s). Moreover, it exhibited anti-interferant ability and long-term stability.[119] Alloy NWs were used in electrochemical sensors for the detection of compounds. Benefiting from the high surface area of 1D nanoarchitecture, the Alloy NWs provided much effective surface exposure at the electrode-electrolyte interface.[120–128]

sections.heading: 3.3.2. Hybrid Nanostructure
sections.text:
1D silver-based hybrid electrodes exhibit fast current response, significant detection limit and wide linear range for electrochemical sensors. Moreover, it offers possibilities for fabricating multifunctional network with new structures and being further applied in portable microfluidic chips for biomedical and biological applications. Wang et.al synthesized a GN-PNF-Ag NW nanohybrid through an electrostatic assembling method. The sensor based on the nanohybrids owned wide linear range, high sensitivity and selectivity, low detection limit and fast current response for detection of H2O2. The CV curve of a GN-PNF-AgNW-modified GCE showed a significant peak (about 32 µA at −0.6 V). The result indicated that Ag NWs exhibited a high electrochemical activity for H2O2 reduction.[80] By combining a trace tag with a disposable immunosensor array, Cao et.al prepared a high sensitive electrochemical immunosensor to detect human immunoglobulin G (IgG) (Figure 9a). The immunosensor showed low detection limit, good specificity, wide linear range and acceptable accuracy to detect antigen.[129] The electrochemical reduction of H2O2 was researched at the GC/Nf/Ag@Cu NWs modified electrode. Figure 9b showed schematic representations of electroreduction of H2O2 at a GC/Nf/Ag seeds electrode (A) and a GC/Nf/Ag@Cu NWs electrode (B). The low OHads on Ag seeds and large distance between the Ag seeds at the GC/Nf/ Ag seeds electrode are eventually attributed to the decrease in autocatalysis. On the other hand, an enhanced reduction peak current at −0.438 V was noticed at the Ag@Cu NWs modified electrode, which proved increase in autocatalysis. In addition, the surface roughness of Ag seeds was improved in the Ag@Cu NWs electrode.[68] Figure 9c depicted the schematic illustration of the CS/Ag NWs/Gox-GCE modified electrode and processes occurring during the enzymatic electrochemical glucose detection. As an efficient catalyst, Ag NWs significantly enhanced the performance of biosensors. Homogeneous dispersion of NWs on the surface of GCE electrode could greatly reduce the H2O2 molecules diffusion distance because of the significantly higher catalytic ability of Ag NWs.[130]
Xu et.al developed a kind of glucose biosensor by adopting 3D hybrid films. It consisted of a high selective and sensitive PBNCs and Ag NWs network. The Ag NW network was built on the electrode with assistance of self-assembled monolayers. The PBNCs were in situ preparation on the Ag NWs network by aerosol deposition. The glucose oxidase was immobilized onto the PBNCs/Ag NWs film by a glutaraldehyde cross-linking method. The fabricated PBNCs/Ag NWs film exhibited high conductivity, large surface area and synergistic electrocatalytic activity. The as-prepared biosensor composed of PBNCs/Ag NWs film exhibited a high sensitivity of 359.0 mA M−1 cm−2 (linear range: 0.01–0.9 mM), an excellent anti-interference capability at a low potential (−0.05 V), outstanding repro ducibility and high stability. The 3D sensing film can be used in quantitative biochemical analysis and biological sensing.[82]
Ag NWs were used in electrochemical sensors, ranging from surface enhanced electrodes to platforms for immobilization of biomaterials. The large surface area-to-volume ratio make them excellent candidates to lead a new generation of sensors with the undoubted advantage of possible
1701091 (14 of 18) www.small-journal.com © 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
reviews
small 2017, 1701091
www.advancedsciencenews.com
incorporation into portable and disposable devices. Here, we compared the electrochemical sensing performance of previously reported Ag-based electrodes, as summarized in Table 2. Although developments in the field are really impressive, the works using Ag NWs in the analysis of real samples remain very scarce, showing that this approach needs to mature for its implementation as a common tool. The fabrication of new platforms of miniaturized sensors involving Ag NWs is therefore a great challenge and holds great promise for a huge range of applications.

sections.heading: 3.4. Electrochemical Catalysis
sections.text:
The performance of alkaline fuel cell (AFC) is restricted by the reaction rate of oxygen reduction on the cathode with high overvoltages. This reaction occurs at the boundary among the oxygen gas, alkaline electrolyte, and the surface of catalyst. The kinetics of ORR relies on various factors, such as limiting current density, ORR potential, catalyst size and catalyst loading. As ORR catalysts, Ag NWs have similar catalytic activities to platinum group metal (PGM)
and platinum alloys while with lower cost. Knott et al. investigated the bulk Ag catalysts which can produce a limiting current density of 0.635 mA cm−2. And Ag NWs catalysts can provide a comparable performance with a lower loading of catalyst. This means that catalyst loadings of silver can significantly decrease by using nanoscaled catalysts, while keeping comparable performance to bulk materials.
Silver alloy NWs also have received extensive attention for electrochemical catalysis. In alloy catalysts, the second metal could tailor the surface and catalytic properties of Ag through ensemble, electronic (ligand) and/or strain effects; these mechanisms could further be manipulated by varying the alloying element, composition, shape, bulk and surface structures, in order to improve the catalytic activity and durability. Kostowskyj et.al applied Ag and Ag-Mn NWs catalysts to the CNT based electrode surface. The Ag and Ag-Mn NWs catalysts can provide comparable catalytic performance with bulk catalysts at a much lower loading. The overpotential and maximum current density exhibited a 0.06 V decrease and an apparent 40–60% increase respectively. Tafel slopes of the CNT, Ag/CNT, Ag-Mn/CNT were ∼70 mV/decade, confirming the ORR activation was limited because of the
(15 of 18) 1701091© 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.small-journal.comsmall 2017, 1701091
www.advancedsciencenews.com
migration of O2 to active surface sites. [71] By reducing AgNO3 and RuCl3 with EG through solvothermal process, Ag-Ru alloy nanorods were synthesized. The nanorods had an average diameter of 40 nm. Ag-Ru alloy nanorods exhibited a better catalytic activity for benzyl chloride by the synergistic effect of Ag and Ru. The results are helpful for future synthesis and application of Ag-Ru catalysts in the field of electrocatalysis.[140]

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions and Outlook
sections.text:
In this review, we have discussed recent progress of 1D silverbased nanomaterials with different nanostructures including 1D simple silver (NWs/rods/belts/alloys), core-shells and hybrids for promoting fascinating applications for electrochemical capacitors, lithium ion batteries, electrochemical sensors and electrochemical catalysis. The rational design of novel nanostructures helps to solve the issues occurred in the electrochemical reactions, dramatically enhancing the performance of electrodes as well as the devices.
To open the door to the next-generation electronic environment, well-matched and high-performance flexible power sources will be the key, with special advantages, such as being bendable, wearable, lightweight, foldable, and having potentially implantable properties. Several inspirational prototypes have been developed, including flexible lithium-ion batteries, Li-O2 batteries, supercapacitors, solar cells and sensors. As a kind of promising electrode materials, Ag NWs have been applied in flexible, transparent and stretchable supercapacitor devices. Ag NWs can considerably enhance the mechanical
stability (flexibility) of electrodes due to their networked structure which can endure bending stress. The stable highcapacity anode is the research focus in the area of LIBs. The conductive network of Ag NWs can preserve the electronic conduction and good pervasion of Li+ and accordingly reduce the internal resistance. Ag NWs were used in electrochemical sensors, ranging from surface enhanced electrodes to platforms for immobilization of biomaterials. The NWs on the electrode introduce a roughened surface with high conductivity and high surface area, which can highly improve catalytic activity. Ag NW-based sensors exhibit excellent performances, such as high Faradaic current density, fast electron transfer rate, high signal-to-noise ratio, low detection limit and enhanced sensitivity. 1D silver-based hybrid electrodes exhibit fast current response, significant detection limit and wide linear range for electrochemical sensors. The large surface area-to-volume ratio offers possibilities for fabricating multifunctional network with new architectures and being further applied in portable microfluidic chips for biomedical and biological applications. Ag NWs have also been studied as the cathode electrocatalyst to promote hydrogen or oxygen peroxide reduction. In ORR, there exists an efficient four-electron reduction for the silver. The morphology of NWs can provide facile electron supply and a large contact area for an effective ORR.
Apart from above advantages of the 1D silver-based nanomaterials, there exist a lot of issues that need to be solved before these materials are used for practical applications. So far, most of the electrochemical applications derived from 1D silver-based nanomaterials are still in an early stage of technical development. The stability of Ag nanomaterials
1701091 (16 of 18) www.small-journal.com © 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
reviews
small 2017, 1701091
www.advancedsciencenews.com
over long time, under high temperature and electrical current is a big issue. Compared to buck Ag materials, the melting point of Ag NWs is relatively low. The lower thermal stability of Ag NWs will limit their applications. To solve the thermal stability issue of Ag NWs, it is a good way to embed AgNW network in the surface of heat resistant polymer film. Heaters based on this method enable rapid heating at lower operation voltages, and show small temperature variation over longtime heating at a constant potential. Another way is to coat Ag NWs with sheaths of tougher materials, which forms nanoscale-type structure. The electrochemical stability of 1D silver nanostructures still needs to be systematically studied and better controlled. Ag NWs often suffer from rapid degradation under a bias voltage, resulting in poor cycle stability. Because the Ag NWs at the anode will be oxidized during the charge exchanging process with the electrolyte. Oxidized AgNWs would lose conductivity at the second time measurement, and the CV diagrams would not have any redox peaks. Some reports have devoted to designing Ag-based nanocomposites with stable morphologies such as the core-shell structure. For Li-ion battery application, similar to tin and silicon, silver also undergoes huge volume changes during charge/discharge reactions leading to electrode cracking and pulverization. Different approaches have been employed to improve the cycling stability such as reducing the dimensions of silver materials, compositing them with carbon, conducting polymers, or by alloying with other metals. Undoubtedly, the overall understanding of silver electrode structures, the interface of electrode/electrolyte, and the charge-storage mechanisms is helpful for future 1D silver-based electrochemical research. At the same time, the transport of ions and electrons in electrolytes and active electrode materials should be deeply investigated by theoretical calculations. Future work is needed to achieve low cost, large-scale preparation, improve cycle stability as well as maintain high compatibility between electrodes with electrolytes as well as device systems.

referenceMentions.context: Finally, Ag NWs were coated on the surface of carbon networks.[81] Xu et al.

This work provided a novel way to improve the performances of OMC based supercapacitors.[81] Another kind of flexible supercapacitors based on Ag NWs was fabricated by sandwiching a porous separator (pre-dipped into Na2SO4 aqueous electrolyte) between two Ag-NW/PEDOT:PSS-NP/MnO2 electrodes (Figure 7l).

metadata.abstractText: One dimensional (1D) silver-based nanomaterials have a great potential in various fields because of their high specific surface area, high electric conductivity, optoelectronic properties, mechanical flexibility and high electro-catalytic efficiency. In this Review, the preparations of 1D silver-based nanomaterials is classified by structure composed of simple silver nanowires/rods/belts/tubes, core-shells, and hybrids. The latest applications based on 1D silver nanomaterials and their composite materials are summarized systematically including electrochemical capacitors, lithium-ion/lithium-oxygen batteries, electrochemical sensors and electrochemical catalysis. The preparation process, tailored material properties and electrochemical applications are discussed.
